elements.label: Penny
elements.desc: The smallest denomination coin, except for the smaller ones.

elements.label: Twopence
elements.desc: Or, if you prefer, 'tuppence'. A sort of Janus of pennies.

elements.label: Threepence
elements.desc: Or 'thruppence', or a 'thruppenny bit'. Like twopence, but more so.

elements.label: Sixpence
elements.desc: The silver coin of least value - but silver, nonetheless.

elements.label: Shilling
elements.desc: Twelve pence or, if you prefer, one-twentieth of a pound.

elements.label: Half Crown
elements.desc: Two and a half shillings. Obviously.

elements.label: Crown
elements.desc: Five shillings; one-quarter of a pound.

elements.label: Ten Shilling Note
elements.desc: Half a pound; but not half a note. A recent innovation.

elements.label: One Pound Note
elements.desc: A noble paper in soothing green. Britannia lounges on her throne, flaming hammer propped insouciantly across her knee.

elements.label: Five Pound Note
elements.desc: 'I promise to pay the Bearer on Demand the Sum of Five Pounds'. The Bearer never does demand, though.

elements.label: Seven Pound Note
elements.desc: Swirls and curlicues in solemn hues. Until recently, one could exchange bank notes for gold in the banks of the capital. A seven-pound note can still be exchanged for rarer metals in rarer places.

elements.label: Payment Received
elements.desc: This could use different levels to indicate the amount paid.
